sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations using block matrices
message_1:
Solve the following system of equations using block matrices:

\[\begin{bmatrix} 3 & 2 \\ 1 & 4 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 5 \\ 8 \end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix} 0 & -1 \\ 2 & -3 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} -1 \\ 3 \end{bmatrix}\]
message_2:
To solve the given system of equations using block matrices, we can write the system as a single block matrix equation:

\[\begin{bmatrix} 3 & 2 & 0 & -1 \\ 1 & 4 & 2 & -3 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \\ x \\ y \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 5 \\ 8 \\ -1 \\ 3 \end{bmatrix}\]

Now, we can rewrite the block matrix equation as a regular matrix equation:

\[\begin{bmatrix} 3 & 2 \\ 1 & 4 \\ 0 & -1 \\ 2 & -3 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 5 \\ 8 \\ -1 \\ 3 \end{bmatrix}\]

We can solve this system of equations using Gaussian elimination or any other method. In this case, we can use the inverse of the matrix to find the solution:

The matrix A is given by:

\[A = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 2 \\ 1 & 4 \end{bmatrix}\]

The determinant of A is:

\[\det(A) = (3)(4) - (2)(1) = 12 - 2 = 10\]

The inverse of A is:

\[A^{-1} = \frac{1}{\det(A)} \begin{bmatrix} 4 & -2 \\ -1 & 3 \end{bmatrix} = \frac{1}{10} \begin{bmatrix} 4 & -2 \\ -1 & 3 \end{bmatrix}\]

Now, we can multiply both sides of the first equation by the inverse of A:

\[A^{-1}A\begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix} = A^{-1}\begin{bmatrix} 5 \\ 8 \end{bmatrix}\]

\[\begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix} = \frac{1}{10} \begin{bmatrix} 4 & -2 \\ -1 & 3 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 5 \\ 8 \end{bmatrix}\]

\[\begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix} = \frac{1}{10} \begin{bmatrix} 4(5) - 2(8) \\ -1(5) + 3(8) \end{bmatrix} = \frac{1}{10} \begin{bmatrix} 4 \\ 19 \end{bmatrix}\]

\[\begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ \frac{19}{5} \end{bmatrix}\]

So, the solution to the system of equations is:

\[x = 2, y = \frac{19}{5}\]
